channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Ukraine Live Updates: As Russia Pounds Ukraine, U.S. Lobbies an Anti-Kremlin Alliance
item.description: Biden spoke with the leaders of Germany, Italy, France and Britain. A Russian missile strike destroyed a Kyiv shopping mall. The Ukrainian foreign ministry accused Russia of forcibly deporting thousands of children.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firemen and emergency workers at the scene of the Retroville Mall on Monday after what appeared to be the most powerful explosion yet in the city of Kyiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Boeing 737-800 Crashes in Remote Mountain Valley in Southern China
item.description: Rescuers on the scene found debris and fires, and a lack of electricity hampered rescue efforts overnight. Search efforts are set to continue into Tuesday, although it was unclear if any of the 132 crew and passengers survived the plane crash.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents in 2019 watched a China Eastern passenger jet preparing to take off on a test flight from the Beijing Daxing International Airport.

item.title: Japan Saved Red-Crowned Cranes. Can They Survive Without Humans?
item.description: Conservators vastly increased the numbers of red-crowned cranes, a symbol of loyalty and longevity in Japanese culture. That’s just a start.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich, Hikari Hida and James Whitlow Delano
item.media:credit: James Whitlow Delano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Red-crowned cranes dancing together in Kushiro.

item.title: How Lviv Has Been Transformed by War
item.description: Simple rituals, like having coffee in a cafe in Lviv, Ukraine, take on a new and sometimes surreal meaning in a radically altered context.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: For millions of internally displaced people, Lviv is the gateway to safety, however fleeting, in the west.

item.title: Tunisian President’s Reform Plan Meets With Skepticism
item.description: President Kais Saied, who has amassed nearly absolute power, launched a consultation he said would lead to a new constitution and elections. But the process has been shunned by many.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:description: A protest rally in Tunis on Sunday against President Kais Saied of Tunisia. About 2,000 people gathered.

item.title: The Lies Putin Tells to Justify Russia’s War on Ukraine
item.description: The Kremlin has used a barrage of increasingly outlandish falsehoods to prop up its overarching claim that the invasion of Ukraine is justified.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has tried to create an alternative reality.

item.title: Creating Space Command, Australia Strengthens High-Tech Bond With U.S.
item.description: The expanded commitment to space defense reflects the reality of a new, extraterrestrial landscape for war.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Defense Minister Peter Dutton of Australia in January.

item.title: Plan for Amazon Headquarters in South Africa in Peril After Court Order
item.description: A judge ordered construction of the development in Cape Town to be halted, saying that the developer had not properly consulted Indigenous South Africans.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: A judge’s order has put a hold on construction of Amazon’s African headquarters in Cape Town.

item.title: Back in U.K., Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe Urges Iran to Release Others
item.description: Ms. Zaghari-Ratcliffe, the British-Iranian charity worker held for six years in Tehran, said “freedom will never be complete” until all detainees were allowed to leave.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe at a Royal Air Force base in England last week after arriving from Iran, where she had been detained for six years.

item.title: ‘I Don’t Have the Right to Cry’: Ukrainian Women Share Their Stories of Escape
item.description: In war, things can change quickly. A New York Times reporter wanted to capture — in whatever blurry way one can in a war — this moment in this war, three weeks in.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian refugees this month in Palanca, Moldova, a village on the border with Ukraine.

item.title: Russia Is Losing Tens of Thousands of Outward-Looking Young Professionals
item.description: Many of them have been streaming into Armenia, where they can work I.T. jobs remotely, at least for a while. At cafes in the capital, Yerevan, the exiles try to plot out new lives from their laptops.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Daro Sulakauri for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Lumen cafe in Yerevan, Armenia, has become one of the hangouts for young Russian professionals who left their country after Russia invaded Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine War Threatens to Cause a Global Food Crisis
item.description: A critical share of the world’s food and fertilizer is stuck in Russia and Ukraine, sending global prices soaring and foreshadowing a rise in world hunger.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:description: Farmers harvesting wheat last year near the village of Tbilisskaya, Russia. A crucial portion of the world’s wheat, corn and barley is trapped in Russia and Ukraine because of the war.

item.title: Devastation and displacement: scenes from the invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: As Omicron Surges and Economy Suffers, China Tweaks ‘Zero Covid’
item.description: Beijing is fine-tuning its virus response playbook to try to limit the cost of restrictions. But its goal of eliminating all infections could make that difficult.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Quarantine workers in Shanghai on Monday, near a neighborhood that had just been locked down.

item.title: Boeing Faces New Upheaval After Crash of Chinese Airliner
item.description: No fault has been found, but the company, which has been trying to overcome a recent legacy of design and production troubles, is likely to get scrutinized.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)
item.media:description: A China Eastern Airlines Boeing 737-800 aircraft in Wuhan, China, last year.

item.title: Russians Pound Ukrainian Cities, as Biden Rallies Anti-Kremlin Alliance
item.description: A powerful explosion ruined a shopping mall in Kyiv and claimed several lives, while Ukraine refused a Russian demand to surrender the devastated city of Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: The remains of the Retroville Mall after what appeared to be the most powerful explosion yet in the city of Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: After Boeing Plane Crash in China, a Desperate Hunt for Survivors
item.description: The plane that crashed in a mountainous area of southern China was carrying 132 people, and rescuers who went to the crash site faced harsh conditions.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Keith Bradsher and Vivek Shankar

item.title: High Death Rate in Hong Kong Shows Importance of Vaccinating the Elderly
item.description: Covid has surged in a number of Asian countries that had once held the virus at bay. Vaccination levels have largely determined how deadly those waves would be.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A community vaccination center last month in Hong Kong, whose older residents have relatively low rates of vaccination.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: The Fight for Mariupol
item.description: Plus a plane crash in China and Hong Kong’s easing of Covid restrictions.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)

item.title: Mariupol Residents Fight to Survive in Bombed and Besieged City
item.description: For three weeks, the Ukrainian port city has been without water, heat, electricity and all communication under a merciless Russian assault. Here’s what its residents have been enduring.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins

item.title: Biden Warns Private Sector of Potential Russian Cyberattacks
item.description: The president cited “evolving intelligence” and urged companies to strengthen their defenses immediately.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden delivering remarks at the White House in Washington last week.

item.title: Ask The Times Your Climate Questions
item.description: Wondering about a word, a scientific phenomenon, a policy or something else? We’re here to help.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times Climate Desk
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times

item.title: As Big Shows of Russian Art End in Europe, Some Wonder What’s Next
item.description: Museums in London and Paris are grappling with questions about how to get art back to Russia, and whether the works will ever be seen again in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall and Vanessa Friedman
item.category: Jewish Museum and Tolerance Center (Moscow, Russia)
The Morozov Collection: Icons of Modern Art (Exhibit)

item.title: England Starts Giving Second Covid Boosters to Vulnerable People
item.description: People over 75, people living in nursing homes and anyone over 12 with a weakened immune system can now get a second booster dose six months after their first.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A National Health Service Covid-19 vaccination center in Blackburn, England, in January. The NHS will offer a fourth vaccine shot to vulnerable groups.

item.title: Myanmar’s Military Committed Genocide Against Rohingya, U.S. Says
item.description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken announced the official designation. More than 9,000 people were killed in the violence.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Rohingya refugees in Kashmir, India, in 2021. The violence in Myanmar’s Rakhine State peaked in August 2017 and forced nearly one million to flee the country.

item.title: The Boeing 737-800 NG is widely used around the world.
item.description: The model involved in the China crash represents nearly 17 percent of the commercial aircraft in operation.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: A Delta Air Lines Boeing 737-800 NG commercial flight lands at New York’s John F. Kennedy International Airport in 2020.

item.title: U.N. Chief Warns of ‘Catastrophe’ With Continued Use of Fossil Fuels
item.description: António Guterres, the United Nations secretary general, said instead of replacing Russian oil, gas and coal, nations must pivot to clean energy.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: António Guterres, the U.N. Secretary General, at the organization's headquarters in New York City this month.

item.title: The Man in the Olive Green Tee
item.description: How President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine transformed the meaning of a piece of cotton.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:description: The Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky addresses the U.S. Congress via video link from Kyiv on March 16.

item.title: How to Avoid Sharing Misinformation on the War in Ukraine
item.description: Here are warning signs to look for before you retweet.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: People fleeing Ukraine at a border crossing in Slovakia. Experts in misinformation say everyone has a responsibility to verify information before sharing it.

item.title: Flight MU-5735 Descended More Than 20,000 Feet in Just Over a Minute
item.description: An hour after it took off, the flight turned horribly wrong, according to data from Flightradar24.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy

item.title: Farmers Describe Scene of China Eastern Airlines Plane Crash
item.description: Witnesses told Chinese news outlets they were at first baffled by the explosion in a rural area. Then, they realized the smoke was coming from what may be China’s worst air accident in decades.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Joy Dong
item.media:description: A still from a video on CCTV, China’s state television, showing emergency personnel preparing to travel to the site of a plane crash in southern China, on Monday.

item.title: The Plane That Crashed Was Not a Boeing 737 Max
item.description: The model is a narrow-body jet that has a maximum range of over 3,000 miles, but is commonly used on shorter routes.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: China Eastern Airlines Boeing 737-800 planes in Taiyuan, China, in 2014.

item.title: The Grimmest Dilemma
item.description: The Biden administration is facing an old Cold War dilemma: Be weak or risk a world war.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shelter in Kyiv.

item.title: China Eastern has not had a deadly crash in 18 years.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Rescuers searched for the black boxes at the crash site of a China Eastern plane in Baotou, in China’s Inner Mongolia region, in 2004.

item.title: Boeing Stock Price Falls After China Eastern Crash
item.description: The aerospace giant said it was seeking more information on the disaster, and U.S. regulators said they were ready to assist.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:description: The Hong Kong stock index on Monday. China Eastern shares finished lower after the crash.

item.title: The Overlooked Stone Carvers of Escolásticas
item.description: A small town in Central Mexico is home to around 200 open-air carving workshops, from which an astonishing array of sculptures continuously emerges.
item.dc:creator: Walter Hodges

item.title: As Inflation Surges, Biden Targets Ocean Shipping
item.description: The president is targeting shipping companies that have jacked up prices during the pandemic, but critics say bigger economic forces are at work.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Coley Brown for The New York Times
item.media:description: The cost to ship a container to the West Coast from China is 12 times higher than it was two years ago.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Russia pummels Mariupol.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A satellite image showing the damage to the Mariupol Drama Theater.

item.title: Hong Kong Will Lift Its Flight Ban for 9 Countries
item.description: Carrie Lam, the chief executive, announced the measures on Monday, as experts said the worst of the latest wave might have passed.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Dale De La Rey/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Hong Kong’s airport on Monday.

item.title: Disney Shanghai temporarily shuts down as Omicron surges in China.
item.description: The move came amid growing restrictions on travel and entertainment across China as the government tries to stamp out the Omicron variant.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:credit: Henri Shi for The New York Times
item.media:description: China is experiencing its worst rise in Covid-19 cases since the early days of the pandemic.

item.title: Brazil Lifts Its Ban on Telegram After Two Days
item.description: Brazil’s Supreme Court blocked Telegram on Friday. The messaging app then responded with measures to fight misinformation, and the court quickly lifted its ban.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
item.media:description: Pavel Durov, chief executive of messenger service Telegram, in San Francisco in 2014.

item.title: Russia Broadens Mariupol Assault as Signs of Stalemate Take Shape
item.description: The battle for Mariupol has become a grim symbol of Russia’s superior firepower and its frustration in failing to subjugate Ukraine after more than three weeks of war.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Marc Santora and Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Planet Labs PBC, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Multiple civilian buildings on fire in Mariupol on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Russia’s Assault on Mariupol
item.description: Plus China’s new Covid strategy and concerns of world hunger.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: Local residents walk near residential buildings which were damaged in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: In Ukraine, Solidarity and Defiance Among Those Still in Kyiv
item.description: About two million people have stayed in Kyiv, a population galvanized by a newfound unity and its refusal to be cowed by Russian invaders.
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: The mostly deserted downtown area of Kyiv on Sunday evening.

item.title: Religion-Fueled Mobs on the Rise Again in Pakistan
item.description: The recent lynching of a man accused of burning pages from a Quran underscored Pakistan’s leading status as a site of religious violence.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman and Salman Masood
item.media:credit: Shahid Saeed Mirza/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The mosque in central Pakistan from which Muhammad Mushtaq was dragged and killed.

item.title: The 9/11 Trial: Why Are Plea Bargain Talks Underway?
item.description: New leadership, an ever receding trial date and pressure to disclose more information about the C.I.A. torture of the accused plotters all contribute.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Shibh, Ramzi Muhammad Abdullah Bin Al-
item.media:description: A pickup truck driving in September through Camp Justice, the court compound at Guantánamo Bay.

item.title: Revered Jewish Sage Buried in One of the Largest Gatherings in Israel’s History
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Israelis shut down large parts of central Israel to attend the funeral of Rabbi Chaim Kanievsky, an influential spiritual leader.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: A vast crowd of ultra-Orthodox Jews surrounded the vehicle carrying the body of Rabbi Chaim Kanievsky to his funeral on Sunday in Bnei Brak, Israel.

item.title: Is Taiwan Next?
item.description: China is watching Russia’s invasion of Ukraine closely.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Taiwan's national flag is seen from a window from a cafe in Dongyin, Taiwan.

item.title: Russian Soldiers Took Their City, Then Their Homes
item.description: As Russian forces pushed toward Kyiv, they stormed an apartment complex in a nearby suburb and held residents hostage. Some of it was caught on camera.
item.dc:creator: Brenna Smith and Masha Froliak

item.title: Hillsong Says Brian Houston, Church Founder, Breached Code of Conduct
item.description: The board of the global megachurch, which got its start in Australia, apologized “unreservedly” to two women who had accused Mr. Houston of inappropriate behavior.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:description: Brian Houston, the Australian founder of Hillsong, stepped away from his ministry duties in January.

item.title: Here are the latest developments in the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah

item.title: Its offensive slowed, Russia uses long-range missiles to devastating effect.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora

item.title: Pope Francis Issues New Vatican Constitution
item.description: The document stipulates that baptized lay Catholics, including women, can lead departments and increases institutional efforts to protect minors.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Pope Francis greeting nuns in January after a weekly general audience at the Vatican.

item.title: Russian Rocket Attack Turns Ukrainian Marine Base to Rubble, Killing Dozens
item.description: More than 40 marines were killed, an official said, but there were signs the toll could much be higher. At the Mykolaiv morgue, dozens of bodies were laid out in a storage area.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers, civilians and emergency workers dug through the remains of the 36th Ukrainian Naval Infantry Brigade headquarters on Saturday. Workers were still trying to recover bodies and survivors from the building, which was hit by a Russian rocket on Friday.

item.title: Spain Endorses Morocco’s Plan for Governing Western Sahara
item.description: Madrid endorsed a plan for limited autonomy for the territory in northwestern Africa, but the change in policy was denounced by independence groups and could aggravate relations with Algeria.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: Fighters with the Polisario Front, which supports independence for Western Sahara, during a training exercise in the territory in October.

item.title: Malawi and 4 Nearby Countries to Begin Polio Vaccination Drives
item.description: The spread of the coronavirus interrupted routine childhood vaccinations globally, opening a door to diseases and compounding the health challenges on the African continent.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.category: Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A clinic last fall in Zambia, one of five African nations preparing polio vaccination drives after a case was found in Malawi. Concerns over polio compound the challenges of fighting the coronavirus.

item.title: Deadly Strike on Ukraine Barracks Punctuates Russian Military Gains
item.description: Ukraine said it had temporarily lost contact with officials in the strategic port city of Mariupol, and a Russian rocket attack on a military site in Mykolaiv left dozens dead.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson, Marc Santora and Valerie Hopkins
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A Ukrainian army position outside of Mykolaiv on Saturday.

item.title: Some U.S. States Reduce Daily Covid Reports
item.description: Some scientists and health experts see the possibility that the first signs of a new surge could be missed, but others say metrics like hospitalizations and wastewater monitoring have become more relevant than daily reports.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coronavirus testing at a drive-through site in Hagerstown, Md., last month. The rise of at-home testing means that official daily reports of cases may be less accurate.

item.title: Ukraine Reminds Georgia of Its Own War With Russia
item.description: Russia invaded Georgia in 2008. To many Georgians, that means the country should stand unequivocally with Ukraine. But the government is more cautious.
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Valya Vanishvili
